Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Morphology Control to Build 3D Magnetic Nanostructures and Tune Organic Solar Cells
Award.AbstractNarration:
Technical: The scientific goal of this CAREER award is to advance the fundamental understanding of organic semiconductors through four interrelated materials science research tasks. The first task focuses on the role of the growth process and grain size distribution, which play a crucial role for the electronic and optical properties of organic materials. The morphology is quantified using methodologies adapted from inorganic thin film studies. The second task is based on a reduction in dimensionality through the fabrication of organic superlattices (coherent multilayers), in which interface properties dominate. Similar structures for metals resulted in the discovery of giant magneto-resistance and the data storage revolution. The PI plans to combine impedance spectroscopy and temperature-dependent measurements to gain insight into the charge transport mechanism of organic superlattices. In collaboration with chemists, the PI will engineer nano-building blocks with ferromagnetic properties that can be tuned as needed. A concept of magnetically tailored one-dimensional ferromagnetic chains is thereby introduced. The fourth task addresses the issue of energy conversion efficiency in organic solar cells. Recently, blends of n- and p-type semiconductors were discovered to significantly increase the performance of organic photovoltaic cells. In a new concept, the PI seeks to build nano-columns based on porous alumina templates that are expected to boost the efficiency and grant additional structural control and potential for optimized design.
Non-technical: The project addresses basic research issues in a topical area of materials science with high technological relevance. Organic semiconductors are valuable for various electronic and photonic applications and potentially large societal impacts. The PI plans to establish a research and teaching laboratory at the California State University, Long Beach, which serves the urban, ethnically and culturally diverse student community. This CAREER award has multiple faceted education impacts. The inclusion of organic semiconductors in the curriculum provides unique and necessary training to students entering a rapidly expanding market for organic semiconductors. Addition of demonstrations to the K-12 Science Learning Center helps convey the relevance of nanotechnology and organic semiconductors.

Interest in non-traditional and novel magnetic systems is strong due to many applications for data storage and sensors. The system of interest here is based on an metallo-organic molecule family, namely metallo-phthalocyanines. One of the molecules, called iron phthalocyanine, shown in figure 2, can be self-assembled on top of substrates into thin films. The magnetic properties are similar to classical 3-dimensional ferromagnets, but have a very different origin. The purpose of this study is to illucidate on the growth mechanism and the origin of the magnetic properties.

Previously, several phases of phthalocyanine in powder were identified. In particular, the alpha and beta phases are distinguished by the different lattice structure.  Recently we were able to show that thin films of iron phthalocyanine have a different columnar stacking order from either of those phases. The new stacking structure is termed thin film phase, as it appears to only occur in thin films. This new crystal lattice is relevant to the magnetic properties of the iron phthalocyanine thin films. In fact, it is a prominent example that by making molecule-based thin films, new magnetic properties are obtained due to the different electronic overlap produced in crystals grown on specific substrates.

Indeed, we previously showed magnetic hysteresis loops for iron phthalcoyanine thin films. Much like a classical ferromagnet, there is an onset temperature for hysteresis, and coercivity values increase in magnitude by lowering the temperature. Recent work, here, revealed strong dynamic effects of the magnetism. One illustration is the coercivity dependence on the sweep speed as illustrated in figure 1. The saturation moment remains constant, but the coercive fields and the remanent fields are reduced for slower measurement sweeping speeds. If one models a finite-sized Ising chain, one would expect a power law dependence of the coercive field with the sweep speed, much like observed in iron phthalocyanine thin films. Indeed, the iron chains formed within the thin film, resemble spin chains of finite-size. The magnetic interaction between iron ions is likely mitigated through super-exchange with the nitrogen at 90 degree angles. The interaction between chains is rather weak at significant temperatures. Therefore, it might be reasonable to expect this system to behave much like a single chain magnet. 

The origin of the magnetism in single chain magnet is based on the slow relaxation of the spins. Indeed, one would not expect long-range coupling in a one-dimensional Ising-like spin system at finite temperatures, if the system is in equilibrium. However, if the relaxation times exceed the measurement times, then, seemingly, ferromagnetic-like properties can be produced by a single chain magnet. 

Depositing thin films, we have a tool with another benefit. Namely, the chain length can be tuned and therefore finite-sized Ising systems can be studied as a function of the chain length. To that extent, we have augmented the literature with results that show how the coercive field is strongly correlated with the spin chain length. Moreover, we have also studied in great detail the dynamic magnetism related to chain length of iron phthalocyanine films grown onto different substrates producing different structures. 

In summary, growth of small molecules in thin films may result in new crystal phases, not accessible in powder form. An example is the thin film phase in iron phthalocyanine. In this case, new magnetic properties result from the new phase. Thin films allow to carefully grow one-dimensional chains in different directions for interesting magnetic characteristics.
